top_comment.text:
The only phobias that I saw on here that affect me are Somniphobia and 
Chorophobia.
Before going to bed at night I have at least one panic attack. I can 
usually fall asleep pretty easily afterward, but the attacks are still 
pretty bad. I think that mainly it's because I'm the kind of person that 
needs stimulation almost constantly, or I'll get stuck in my head and start 
worrying about things. And nighttime is when things start winding down and 
other people go to bed. It's gotten to the point where the idea of sleep 
itself starts to frighten me.

As far as Chorophobia goes, I get scared when I'm asked to dance in public. 
This fear came from when I was in 7th grade and everyone was dancing. I 
tried to dance, despite knowing that I couldn't, and was immediately shot 
down by just about everyone. Some were laughing, some were giving me faces 
of disgust, some were even getting mad at me for wasting their time, I 
guess was what it was. The next day everyone kind of looked at me funny. I 
never wanted to experience anything that disheartening again.﻿

top_comment.text:
I have Trypophobia. I get very uneasy and freaked out when I see tiny 
holes.. especially when clustered together. For example: makeup mirrors 
that zoom as close to as your skin pores freaks me out; along with honey 
combs of bee hives, rain drops on loose dirt, bread sometimes, Surinam Toad 
with their offspring, close up of eyes ( as semi cool as it looks ), garlic 
when cut... this shit freaks me out so much my skin is beginning to crawl 
and now I feel sick.. 
Is this unreasonable? That's an opinion, but it simply grosses and freaks 
me out.

 I think it started one day when I was in my elementary years.. I shook a 
pine tree after it had rained and the raindrops on the branches fell onto 
loose dirt beneath... leaving multiple small holes... I stopped and stared 
at it in shock.. it made me think little maggots were going to crawl out.. 
( I also hate maggots, if that ties into this phobia? ) .. the recess 
supervisor had to tell me recess was over and walk me to class because of 
the strange trauma it gave me.. I remember that day being the first time I 
found my phobia.. of course I was too young to know it was a real phobia.. 
and now my friends love to search trypophobia on my Google searches at 
school when I'm not looking.. they think its funny.. I suppose it kind of 
is if I were on the other end, but I'm not. Anyone else relate?﻿

Oh I get that. Its not a phobia. Unless it fills you with terror that you 
honestly cannot control. Phobias are debilitating, rather than something 
you'd simply rather avoid. I can't stand the lines and edges of things

aspergers syndrome because every doctor seems to think everything 
weird/wrong with me is because of it.

comments.text:
OH NO, you are so right!  I had to analyze it for a very long time now.  I 
know what I FEAR......... I FEAR that the Christians are lying and that 
they won't rapture out of here, and that I will never get the planet to 
myself. 

Every day I wake up, and go "Damn it!   They are still here!  They promised 
to go!  When the hell are they going to leave?  They are such incredible 
liars!"   So, I am incredibly fearful that I have listened to bull shit for 
years, and believed.

I mean I wanted to go big game hunting and not buy a hunting license!  I 
wanted to drive to the state capitol at any speed I want with out risking 
a  speeding ticket!  I wanted to pick any car off the dealers lot and not 
pay for it!  I wanted to go pick any clothes off the department store 
shelves, not pay for it and when it got dirty I could just burn it or throw 
it out the backdoor, and go get some more!  No more standing in line at the 
check out either!  No more taxes!  I can pave anything I want and build 
anything I want without a permit!  Wouldn't that  just be 
awesome!...............

So, my fear is that they have lied, and that they are really not leaving!  
What's that called  (fear of the rapture not taking place)?  It has to have 
a name doesn't it?......ANTIRAPTUREPHOBIA?  DERAPTUREPHOBIA?  Got any ideas?

No seriously......... I've been dead not once, but twice.   After that you 
just don't have any fears left, and very few if any questions 
left.......just annoyances.

comments.text:
+ShogunGin0
On the contrary......I find that most people with many fears are are 
ignorant savages.  When a person is uneducated in a subject, that is what 
they fear.  People who have experienced death, have no fear of death.  
People who have been through physical, or mental torture, tend to not fear 
those things because they know that they can survive them, or overcome 
them, the alternative is only death.  People who grew up staying up all 
night,  working all night, or not running the lights at night, have no fear 
of the dark.  Some people are afraid of spiders.   They fear them because 
they have never studied them.  You fear, only what you do not understand.  
The better educated a person is on a subject, the less they fear.  It is 
only when a person's knowledge of a subject is quiet limited that they fear 
something.   Therefore, fear is of the unknown.   The less that the person 
knows, the more they fear.  It is not to say that one does not gain a 
healthy respect to avoid certain potential life threatening situations.  
Avoiding those things is not the same as fear, in fact that is actually 
what is referred to as MORALS.  Learning the moral to the story.  If you 
can learn by the mistakes of others then you have MORALS.  If you survive 
your own mistakes then you will develop NO FEAR..

Here is just some of my fears |
Altophobia- Fear of heights.
Anginophobia- Fear of angina, choking or narrowness.
Antlophobia- Fear of floods.
Anuptaphobia- Fear of staying single.
Arachnephobia or Arachnophobia- Fear of spiders.
Asthenophobia- Fear of fainting or weakness.
Athazagoraphobia- Fear of being forgotton or ignored or forgetting.
Autophobia- Fear of being alone or of oneself.
Ballistophobia- Fear of missiles or bullets.
Cancerophobia or Carcinophobia- Fear of cancer.
Cleithrophobia or Cleisiophobia- Fear of being locked in an enclosed place.
Cnidophobia- Fear of stings.
Diabetophobia- Fear of diabetes.
Emetophobia- Fear of vomiting.
Eremophobia- Fear of being oneself or of lonliness.
Hadephobia- Fear of hell.
Hamartophobia- Fear of sinning.
Harpaxophobia- Fear of being robbed.
Herpetophobia- Fear of reptiles or creepy, crawly things.﻿

You forgot the only phobia I have, and I am very flustered that I have it. 
Cetaphobia. It's really uncommon, so that's why I'm upset about it. But 
it's the irrational fear of whales. I have a very different form of 
cetaphobia though, it's not just the big whales, it's any defined whale. A 
killer whale does not frighten me one bit because it's an "orca" which is a 
branch of whale but more... Less frightening to me. I can be afraid of any 
whale you put in front of me but if you put something that isn't a whale 
but looks like a whale in front of me, I wont be terrified. I think it's 
the dorsal fin that makes it less frightening. But I purely hate my 
cetaphobia because it's stupid, I can't go to any water park with whales in 
it.﻿

top_comment.text:
People listing all of dozens your "phobias", fuck off. Disliking or being 
scared of something doesn't equal a phobia. A phobia is when you literally 
cant do anything because you're so scared, your heart feels like it's going 
to burst out of your chest, you cant breathe properly, you just want to run 
and scream and get away from the thing thats causing this. Even just 
thinking about that thing can bring about a reaction. "Ewww a spider!" isnt 
Arachnophobia. Arachnophobia is when just seeing a spider web terrifies 
you, you couldn't bear to even think about being in the same room as one, 
and if you were, you'd probably start hyperventilating and burst into 
tears. When you start claiming you have all these phobias, you undermine 
all the people who really do have serious fears, and who cant go about 
their normal daily lives because of them. Stop attention seeking. Nobody 
gives a fuck.
Rant over.﻿
top_comment.author: NetherwingEgg

comments.text:
+NetherwingEgg Sorry to inform you friend (not trying to argue, not trying 
to discount anyone with a phobia, simply trying to help you understand) But 
phobias are not just the worst of the worst, a phobia simply refers to an 
irrational fear/dislike often extreme, but not exclusively. If you are 
afraid of clowns, it is irrational, and therefore a phobia, if you get 
mildly mad at clowns for no reason, it's a phobia. For instance, I myself 
have entomophobia, and though I only very rarely receive panic attacks 
because of this, it is still a phobia. Severity has nothing to do with 
phobia, the irrational part is the important part. A fear of being stabbed 
multiple times in the neck, is not a phobia, because it is rational, the 
fear of drowning, also not a phobia, but the fear of knives, and the fear 
of water itself, those are phobias.

comments.text:
+Mr. Hanky They're not idiots. Sorry to say dude but if I remember anything 
from psychology class it's that phobias are often totally irrational and 
the people who have them very often know that, but that doesn't make it 
possibly to just get over it. Many phobias form from one or more 
experiences in a person's life that make them either consciously or 
unconsciously associate a stimulus (the thing they become afraid of) with 
extremely unpleasant feelings. Some fears like the fear of spiders are 
possibly a semi-innate fear passed down through generations from a time 
where spiders might have been more dangerous, just as some people fear the 
dark etc. My deep fear of injections and blood tests for example is mostly 
irrational and I know that, but I will always associate those needles with 
getting vaccinated as a kid and the fact that it happened to hurt a lot at 
the time and the nurses were scaring me. I know someone who has a severe 
fear of dogs because they were chased/attacked by one in childhood and 
never forgot it. People usually know there's no reason to fear the thing so 
much, but the mind is a complicated thing making it impossibly to just 
shove that fear away permanently. It takes time and sometimes certain forms 
of therapy or gradual exposure to get over it.

Well. I guess you can take it from another approach? Not many of us accept 
the fact that we might just die any moment. Therefore, not many of us learn 
to cherish what we already have cos we take them for granted. There's no 
need to be fearful of death. We will die sooner or later. Instead of 
fearing it, embrace the fact that you are actually uniquely special as you 
are aware of death while the rest of us are not always aware of it. Once 
you embrace that fact, you will be able to cherish everything you have, 
unlike the rest of us. We are just ungrateful cos we are almost oblivious 
to the fact that we might just drop dead anytime.

That depends on the severity of the phobia. Mild sufferers obviously don't 
have this issue. I can talk about my phobias all day long with no adverse 
affects to myself. because I actually have to be in those situations before 
they actually trigger. DangerDolan was talking sufferers with highly severe 
reactions to their phobias and severity depends on the individual. There 
are also specific triggers for each individual as well. I have 
claustrophobia. Talking or thinking about it doesn't trigger the 
hyperventilation (a symptom of a panic attack) but being full restrained to 
the point where I can't move does.

When he showed the picture at 0.07 (a lotus pod), he was alluding to the 
fear known as trypophobia, or the fear of small holes.  It is a very real 
thing, and I actually suffer from it mildly.

Those lotus pods may not look gross to you know, but go to Google Images 
and type in "trypophobia".  If you have a weak stomach, I wouldn't 
recommend it.  You have been warned.﻿

top_comment.text:
I have these phobias =>
(Inspired by BloodBornFreak)
- Coulrophobia (Fear of clowns)
- Ligyrophobia ( Fear of loud noises/sounds)
- Ophidiophobia ( Fear of snakes)
- Lepidopterophobia ( Fear of moths)
- Pediophobia ( Fear of dolls)
- Astraphobia ( Fear of thunderstorms)
- Claustrophobia ( Fear of confined spaces)
- Pupaphobia ( Fear of puppets )
- Decidophobia ( Fear of making decision/making the wrong decision)
- Athazagoraphobia ( Fear of being forgotten)
- Turophobia (Fear of cheese)
- Papaphobia (Fear of the Pope)
- Apeirophobia (Fear of Infinity)
- Aulophobia (Fear of flutes)
- Siderodromophobia (Fear of trains)
- Ecclesiophobia  (Fear of churches)
- Selachophobia  (Fear of sharks)


THATS NOT ALL!﻿

It annoys me how nearly everybody seems to say that they're afraid of 
clowns. Considering that the circus is practically nonexistent anymore, I 
don't see how many people could actually even see a clown in real life in 
order to instill that fear. You see them a lot in horror movies, sure, but 
what makes them any creepier than any other horror villain?
Maybe it's just me, but I don't see anything particularly interesting about 
clowns at all. They're really nothing more than a cheap cliché for horror 
movies and haunted houses. Same goes for chainsaws. I'm sick of seeing 
chainsaws everywhere in horror franchises.﻿

comments.text:
+Silent Hill Brony Now you're just bashing in a narcissistic rant. +Ethan 
Ball has pointed out the reasoning behind his comment and has made a fair 
point (+ Defense) while you simply rant like he's an asshole who claims to 
be homophobic. So let's make some things clear and hope you understand 
clearly;

- Just because someone is a homophobic doesn't mean they're a freak of 
nature. Guess how gays were viewed for thousands of years? Freaks of 
nature. Guess how blacks were viewed when the religious crusades of the 
Medieval era started? Freaks of nature. However, both are natural.
Now in the modern world, we have phobias being recognized more often. Fear 
of bugs, animals, the colour yellow, water, heights, even fear of ducks 
watching you. And if there's phobias, there's misplaced anger. So why is 
Homophobia bashed on? Because only Homophobia has been recognized 
throughout history (At least as the biggest one).

So with that in mind, you have *no valid* reason to bash on Homophobia. You 
wouldn't like it if I bashed on your fear of people, would you? As a person 
trying to change their ways to be better, you're being pathetic about it; 
intentionally avoiding keeping an open mind in situations and throwing 
narcissistic rants.

- Speaking of open minds, you pass of Homophobia because I only developed 
one justification. Guess what? Homophobia almost levels on fear of people 
if the person is paranoid enough. So I *dare* you to shoot down the one 
justification that - by the way - covers your phobia as well. Go on, I'm 
waiting.

- Another changing issue you're facing is you're *fighting* something, not 
calmly resolving it. You may as well be the KKK expressing their opinions 
on non-Whites; that's accurately how you're handling this.

- And you're being *highly* hypocritical. You bash on +Ethan Ball (Among 
other Homophobics) like they're being keyboard warriors whilst defending 
Homophobia, yet here you are caps locking your poorly constructed argument 
and destroying any structure you make. You basically defeat your own 
argument.

In summary; Grow the fuck up. If something exists, there's probably a 
phobia for it. And if there is, you have *no right* to shoot it down like 
an abomination. Otherwise you simply show yourself off as any religious 
xenophobe of the religious crusades, and any decent person will not want to 
take you decently, if at all.

top_comment.text:
I have entomophobia, the fear of insects. This one is pretty common, but I 
seem to be more extreme. I think it started when I was little and, like 
many, I was afraid of bugs because they were things I didn't commonly see 
and looked foreign. However, that fear never went away and got worse.

For instance, a couple months ago a brown mamorated stink bug landed next 
to me in my room. I charged out of the room and began crying and 
hyperventilating in the hallway, and I wasn't able to go into my room for 
another half hour.

Flies and smaller insects like pantry moths don't bother me, but bigger 
ones make me go insane. The thing I hate is how people belittle me because 
I'm terrified of a 3 inch creature I could easily squash. I know it's 
irrational and stupid, but it doesn't stop me from being afraid!﻿

comments.text:
Its a vaccine that has three injections: measles, mumps and rubella its 
very common to be vaccinated with them.

In case you dont know how a vaccine works they inject a dead version of the 
disease (so you dont die) into you training your body to use the right 
antibodies against them so that if you get it in future your body can deal 
with it easily. Same reason you only get chickenpox once and if you dont 
get it then your encouraged to try and get chicken pox at a young age where 
its not dangerous rather than when you are older it can kill you.

top_comment.text:
I don't really know how to name my phobia. Can someone help me? Here goes. 
Imagine you opened your eyes and you were in space/universe. Now imagine 
how big it was. Now let me explain this part. The other day I played this 
game called "Lego:Star wars III" with my little brother. Now if you ever 
played that game you would know that you can go to space with your ship. So 
I was going to space when suddenly my little bro triggered some mission 
where you had to destroy all the bombs in space to progress. I was 'kinda' 
ok with it untill lots of them started to explode. Idk how I felt, I guess 
scared. I felt like when all of them started to explode, they started to 
spread. You know, when a bomb goes off, it's smoke and remainings go way 
off into the distance. So when all of them went off I just realized how big 
all of that was and I got scared. Really. Maybe some of you know how it 
felt. I know that it was just a video game, but I felt so afraid. The way 
all of the bombs went off, the way they spread, and the way the universe 
was so big. A strange, but scary sensation went through my head when I saw 
all of that, and I felt afraid. Does anyone know what that phobia is?﻿

thankfully medicated these days, but going a long time without looking into

captions.text:
• We're all paranoid about something, but
certain people take it to extremes

• From phobias of beauty to fear of the
unknown, we count 20 of the most outrageous

mental conditions ever to inflict the human
race

20 - A fear of long words
• This one is rather ironic, and a kind

of cruel
• People who have a fear of long words need

to deal with the fact that their phobia is
clinically titled Hippopotomonstrosesquipedaliophobia

• Whoever came up with the name is a bit
of a jerk

19 - Xanthophobia
• This is an irrational fear of the colour

yellow, which could be the sun, flowers or
buildings covered in yellow paint

• It comes in varying levels of aggressiveness,
but the worst kind is when you can't even

hear the word yellow without having a panic
attack

18 - Aphenphosmphobia
• The fear of touching or being touched,

mostly centred around humans of the opposite
gender

• It usually develops as a result of sexual
or physical assault, but it's been known to

appear even without a trigger
• If it isn't already obvious, this phobia

pretty much kills any chance of intimacy
17 - Caligynephobia

• Likewise, this one is the unwarranted
fear of beautiful women, usually in men young

and old though more common in those who don't
have a straight orientation

• It causes panic attacks, uncontrollable
social problems and a lack of attendance at

beauty contests
16 - Coulrophobia

• The infamous fear of clowns - predominantly
found in small children, as well as adults

who may have had a questionable encounter
with them in their youth

• Unlike quite a few other phobias, whoever
had this usually knows their phobia is irrational

and unwarranted, but they still can't escape
those foreboding facial features, the swollen

nose, the weird colour scheme, and also IT
by Stephen King. That doesn't help.

15 - Turophobia
• The fear of cheese, usually stemming from

a traumatic experience like, you were once
chased down the street by a psycho murderer

wielding some delicous blue vein
• This one can be diverse, you either fear

a specific type of cheese or the entire batch
• It's made even worse if you also have

that yellow colour phobia from earlier
14 - Cacophobia

• The fear of ugliness - and not just of
people, but anything ugly or imperfect, either

situation or object, it doesn't matter, either
can set you off

• Nobody's really sure what causes this
phobia, but it likely stems from a traumatic

event involving ugliness where you're conditioned
to respond to a certain stimulus, in this

case, that which you perceive to be flawed
or unattractive

13 - Ablutophobia
• There's a separate fear of cleaning yourself,

but this one takes it a step further
• It's the inability to engage in personal

hygiene because of how terrifying the experience
is

• You'll find this mostly in children or
women, usually stemming from serious mental

trauma
12 - Deipnophobia

• The fear of dinner conversation
• This is a byproduct of the larger social

phobia, but more specifically targeting the
chaotic and unpredictable nature of talking

to people around a table
• It's been speculated that Howard Hughes

famous from the Aviator film starring Leonardo
DiCaprio had this, as one scene involves him

awkwardly trying to compose himself while
having a dinner with a family

11 - Somniphobia
• The fear of sleeping, it encompasses a

broad range of types and people usually suffer
from a very mild form at a young age, getting

used to the cycle of sleep, unconsciousness
then revival

• Some people don't get over this though,
for those it feels like dying every night,

or it's the lack of control over the situation
that sets them off, or maybe the nightmares

are keeping them awake, or uncontrollable
insomnia - it could be a vast number of things

10 - Novercaphobia
• The fear of stepmothers, this one should

be fairly obvious since foster parents usually
bring negative feelings to children, both

in real life but moreso in the media
• Stepmothers in films are typically portrayed

as cruel, or as a witch mistreating the kids
under their care, and it only encourages this

phobia
9 - Spectrophobia

• This is a phobia for vampires - the fear
of one's own reflection in the mirror, or

indeed the dread of mirrors themselves
• It mostly comes from horror movies constantly

pausing on mirrors, heightening tension, seeing
ghostly forms in the mirror

• People start seeing the same thing in
real life, and we all get it from time to

time, usually in the middle of the night,
in an empty house, something just over your

shoulder...
8 - Gymnophobia

• This is the fear of nudity, one very common
these days

• It refers to both the anxiety of someone
seeing YOU naked, and likewise you seeing

someone else naked, then getting stuck with
the mental image of their nakedness

• The reason for this fear? The feeling
of physical inadequacy, that people will point

out your flaws and vulnerability, and that,
like George Costanza, you happened to be in

the pool just before you were caught
7 - Hylophobia

• The fear of trees, or more specifically,
dark foreboding woods

• Like with a lot of these phobias, it got
worse once mainstream media started releasing

movies like Friday the 13th set in a cabin
in the woods

• It usually develops in children, but it
carries over into adulthood and even the mere

mention of woods can set someone off
6 - Demonophobia

• The fear of demons, this one should be
fairly self explanatory

• It extends from the fear of a religious
hell, to physical demonic beings roaming the

earth, and likewise possessions for fans of
exorcist movies

• Most who have this phobia are aware demons
aren't around, but the subconscious terror

persists
5 - Vestiophobia

• The fear of clothing and of being clothed
• This one makes it difficult to operate

in society, and sufferers will tend to wear
the baggiest, minimalistic clothing possible

so that the least possible amount of material
touches their skin

• Some go to extremes, never leave their
homes, and stay naked 24/7

• These people aren't very good at strip
poker

4 - Chorophobia
• The fear of dancing, whether it be themselves

dancing, being in a room of other people dancing
- it's all the same unbridled tap-dancing

terror
• Most of the time it borders more on the

sufferer being uncomfortable or embarrassed
than scared, since dancing is another social

cue some can't get the hang of
3 - Neophobia

• The fear of new things or experiences
• It can be mild, the unwillingness to break

from routine or try new things is usually
an indicator someone you know might suffer

from this phobia
• It's also diverse, you can also be angry,

frustrated or anxious about some new technology
or revolution and that'd make you neophobic

2 - Nomophobia
• This one is recent, and also retarded:

the fear of being without mobile phone coverage
• It's a phobia, about losing bars on your

phone screen, or running out of battery, or
losing sight of your damn phone like its the

one ring of Mordor
• According to studies, nearly half of civilised

humans suffer from this phobia
1 - Phobophobia

• This is when you're afraid of phobias,
when you're afraid of f ear itself

• Think about when you suspect the lump
on your neck might be dangerous, how obsessive

and panicky you get - that's phobophobia,
fear of something you don't know

• It's not caused by an outside source,
it's simply projected from your own internal

sentiment, your own fears projected on to
an object or thing

title: 20 Unreasonable Phobias, Some We Might Already Have
